Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_0.name: 9bc5
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_0.text: Deploying a React App to AWS S3

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_1.name: df69
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_1.text: How to use CI/CD pipelines to automate your build process

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_2.name: 22b6
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_2.text: Photo by Justin Lim on Unsplash

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_3.name: be7f
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_3.text: Being a software engineer is not just about coding and building projects. It’s a massive ecosystem consisted of requirement analysis, designing, development, deploying, maintaining, etc.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_4.name: 3e18
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_4.text: So it’s essential to automate things to reduce the time and focus on the development process’s core functionalities. We can use CI/CD tools to manage such situations easily.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_5.text: In this article, I’m planning to integrate the GitHub repo and AWS S3 bucket to automate the deployment of a React application using a CI/CD tool named Buddy.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_6.text: Before that, let’s get a simple understanding of CI/CD tools.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_8.name: 202e
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_8.text: Continuous integration, continuous delivery, and continuous deployment (CI/CD) have been used in the software development industry for a long period. CI/CD practices can contribute similarly in both infrastructure and internally developed applications. Many organizations use CI/CD tools to automate different phases of their application build.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_9.name: 12a4
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_9.text: There are diverse Of CI/CD tools, but they all use closely related models. When choosing a CI/CD tool, you have to consider whether it is hosted or not, whether the UI is user friendly and simple to use, and whether it keeps up with Docker. An interesting fact is that CI/CD practices will help place you in a better position to guide your organization through this novel practice. Rather, you will be a guide for everyone else to follow.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_11.name: ca84
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_11.text: Recently, I came across this fantastic user-friendly CI/CD tool called Buddy that builds, tests, and deploys applications using code from GitLab, Bitbucket, and GitHub. It utilizes Docker containers with pre-installed languages and frameworks to build on, monitor, and notify actions. Buddy helps you to design delivery pipelines to build, test, and deploy your application on a single branch push. The pipelines comprise steps you can configure according to your requirements.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_12.name: 52c5
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_12.text: In this article, let’s see how to deploy your React application to AWS S3 using Buddy. Here we go!

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_13.text: Task 1. Create a New IAM User Role in AWS

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_14.name: 9b5f
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_14.text: Log in to your AWS console, select IAM service, and then select Users. Then choose Add User, and you will be redirected to a UI like this where you can give a name to the new user. Select “Programmatic access” as the access type and continue to the permission section.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_16.name: be6d
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_16.text: In the permission section, select the “Attach existing policies directly” tab and select “AmazonS3FullAccess” from the list below.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_18.name: a756
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_18.text: After successfully creating a user, you will receive the Access Key ID and Secret Access Key, which will be used later to make a connection between the CI/CD pipeline and AWS services. Make sure you download and save those IDs.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_20.name: 26c9
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_20.text: Task 2. Create an S3 Bucket and Enable Static Site Hosting

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_21.name: f2cf
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_21.text: This is a straightforward step. You just need to go to the S3 service using your AWS console and create a new bucket. Please make sure to remove the tick from “Block all public access” to make the bucket public.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_23.name: 2b2d
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_23.text: After creating the bucket, add the following policy as a bucket policy:

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_25.name: b7b6
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_25.text: As the final step of bucket creation, you need to go to the properties section to enable the static hosting option for your bucket. Once you are done, you will receive a URL for the bucket.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_27.name: 0d0a
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_27.text: Task 3. Create a New Project/Select Your Git Repository

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_28.text: Next, if you haven’t yet, sign up with Buddy or log in using your GitHub, Bitbucket, or Google account.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_29.name: 155e
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_29.text: Once you have logged in to your Buddy account, you can get started by creating a new project. You will be able to select your Git provider and repository in this stage. Once you finalize them, click the “Create a new project” button to confirm.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_30.name: badd
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_30.text: Buddy allows you to connect with all the popular Git providers including GitHub, Bitbucket, GitLab, and private repositories with few clicks.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_33.text: To automate your React application, add a new delivery pipeline. Enter the pipeline name, trigger mode, and the branch from which Buddy will obtain your code. Then click the “Add a new pipeline” button to continue.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_34.name: 13dd
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_34.text: “Branch allocation” is specifying the branch that Buddy will deploy from. If you adjust the trigger mode to “On push,” on each push to that branch, Buddy executes the pipeline.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_35.name: 34eb
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_35.text: Considering trigger modes, Manual (on click) is recommended for production, “On push” (automatic) for development, and Recurrently (on time interval) for staging/testing.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_38.name: d004
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_38.text: Next you should add a new action to the pipeline. Buddy facilitates several different approaches for deploying your project and lets you pick from hundreds of prespecified actions. I will add two actions in this scenario that will execute the following tasks:

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_39.name: 9f08
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_39.text: Build the React app: download dependencies (npm, Yarn), compile assets.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_40.name: f6e0
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_40.text: Deploy the React App to AWS S3

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_41.name: fec1
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_41.text: It is possible to manage React builds using the Node.js action. You can select the environment information and specify the commands to be executed.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_42.name: b48e
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_42.text: You can either use a single Node action to run all npm commands or use dedicated actions for each command. In this example, I will be using dedicated actions for each command.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_43.name: de91
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_43.text: First, add an npm install command to make sure all your dependencies and libraries are in place for the build process.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_45.name: 0bd2
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_45.text: If you have any tests to run before deploying the project, Buddy provides options to run test automation using its pipeline easily. You can use another Node action to execute tests in your project using the relevant command. In my case, it's npm run test.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_46.name: aa7f
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_46.text: Then add another Node action to execute the npm run build command to build the project.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_47.name: a6ed
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_47.text: If you need to test those commands, you can simply run the pipeline manually before moving on to the next steps. If there are any errors, you can find them in action logs.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_49.name: adaa
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_49.text: Scroll down and click on S3 on the actions list.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_51.name: bed4
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_51.text: Configure AWS integration and enter the name of your integration. Paste the Access Key Id and Secret Access Key from the AWS console that you copied. Click on the “Add integration” button.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_54.name: 11cc
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_54.text: Then configure action information, choose the Bucket ID you want to upload your files to. Set the “Source path” to “/build” since your project build directory id is “source/build.” Also, make sure that you have selected Pipeline Filesystem as the source since you build the project using the pipeline in the previous action. Finally, click on the “Add this action” button.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_56.name: 170c
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_56.text: Now your pipeline is all set to deploy your React application to AWS S3.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_57.name: 21af
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_57.text: What if you want to get notifications about the deployment? Buddy has an answer for that too.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_58.name: b327
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_58.text: Scroll down and move to Notifications. From the right-hand side of the page, select the service of your choice. I’ll choose Slack, a popular notification service among Buddy users. As you’re adding a third-party service to your pipeline, you will need to configure integration details. Here you can decide the scope of the integration.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_60.name: 6b6b
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_60.text: Finally, you have to accept the OAuth permissions of the chosen application:

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_62.name: ea4d
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_62.text: Then you can specify the notification message as your wish.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_64.name: a098
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_64.text: Once someone pushes changes to your Git repository and executes the pipeline, you will be notified.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_66.name: 9d1d
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_66.text: Now you are all set, and the completed pipeline will look like this:

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_69.name: 7b50
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_69.text: Once you push changes to your Git repository, your pipeline will execute and deploy your React application to AWS S3.

Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_72.name: 481b
Paragraph:d31ac24116a1_72.text: Automation has become a necessity to escape from the complexities of the modern software development process. CI/CD tools make it possible to efficiently deliver the applications with new, enriched features to the users. Tools like Buddy assist us in this role, allowing developers to build pipelines to perform actions for a wide variety of technologies and integrate them to address the most unique and essential needs.
